# Obtaining a temporary registration certificate

A temporary registration certificate, or "transit", can be issued by the SAAQ or a dealer to allow a vehicle to operate on public roads in Québec for a limited period of time.

Various types of temporary registration certificates can be issued. Here are the most common cases:

- a vehicle sold by a dealer
- a stored vehicle acquired by a dealer, a non-resident of Québec or someone else
- a mechanical inspection
- a vehicle registered for operation in a location that is not connected to the Québec road network
- a trip permit for a heavy vehicle
- a recalibration of the advanced driver assistance systems after a severely damaged vehicle has been rebuilt

For more information on other situations where you could obtain a temporary registration certificate, consult the [Politique sur l'immatriculation temporaire (PDF, 201.3 KB)⁠ ⁠](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/blob/saaq/documents/publications/acces-information/immatriculation-temporaire.pdf) (in French only) or [phone us](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/reach-us).

### A temporary registration certificate cannot be issued for:

- a discarded vehicle, unless a mechanical inspection certificate confirming that the vehicle meets the applicable standards is provided
- an unregistered hand-crafted vehicle, unless a mechanical inspection certificate confirming that the vehicle meets the applicable standards is provided, or unless the vehicle is a hand-crafted trailer weighing 900 kg or less
- a severely damaged vehicle, except where the advanced driver assistance systems are being recalibrated
- an unrebuildable vehicle (total loss)
- an ATV, a snowmobile or any other vehicle not designed for operation on public roads

This means that these vehicles must always be towed or transported to be moved.

## Vehicle sold by a dealer

A temporary 10-day registration certificate can be issued by a dealer to allow a vehicle to operate on public roads and be registered at one of our [service outlets](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/find-service-outlet).

You must affix the certificate on the upper left side of the vehicle's rear window and keep the **Attestation de transaction avec un commerçant** form that you received from the dealer in the vehicle.

## Stored vehicle acquired by a dealer, a non-resident of Québec or someone else

We can issue a temporary 4-day registration certificate if any of the following applies to your vehicle:

- it is registered to be used exclusively on a private road
- it has been acquired in Québec by a non-resident
- it has been stored and now needs to be repaired, modified, weighed, checked or inspected
- it belongs to a duly licensed dealer
- it has been sold by a duly licensed dealer or a manufacturer for delivery purposes

### To request a 4-day certificate

Come to one of our [service outlets](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/find-service-outlet) and present the following documents:

- your driver's licence or another official photo ID document

AND

- one of the following documents:
  - the vehicle registration certificate issued in Québec
  - the vehicle registration certificate issued by another Canadian province or territory
  - the **Title** form or the **Salvage Certificate** signed by the former owner (if the vehicle comes from the United States) as well as the sales contract or invoice in your name
  - the vehicle registration certificate in the name of the former owner as well as the sales contract or invoice in your name
  - the **Description du véhicule neuf** form or the **Certificate of Origin for a Vehicle**
  - the vehicle import form
  - a valid mechanical inspection certificate, if the vehicle has been stored or has not been authorized for road use for more than 12 months

### If you cannot come to the service outlet in person

- If you are an individual, the person who goes to the service outlet to request a temporary registration certificate for you must bring the original of the [Power of Attorney (PDF, 657.0 KB)⁠](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/blob/saaq/documents/formulaires/power-attorney-form.pdf) form completed by you.
- If your business owns the vehicle and none of its directors can be present, the person responsible for requesting the registration certificate must bring the original of a document authorizing that person to act on its behalf.

## Mechanical inspection

We can issue a temporary 12-hour registration certificate if:

- you have invoices or proof demonstrating that the mechanical defect indicated on the mechanical inspection certificate has been repaired
- the mechanical inspection certificate indicates that a minor defect was not repaired within 48 hours or that neither the SAAQ nor a [mechanical inspection centre](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/find-service-outlet) has verified if your vehicle meets standards
- your vehicle, which is required to undergo a [periodic mechanical inspection](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/transportation-goods/mechanical-inspection-and-maintenance/mandatory-mechanical-inspection), does not have a valid inspection sticker because you did not follow the mechanical inspection calendar

Your vehicle **must not**:

- have been discarded
- have been declared a severely damaged or unrebuildable vehicle

A temporary 12-hour registration certificate cannot be renewed. This registration certificate is issued free of charge.

### To request a 12-hour certificate

Go to one of our [service outlets](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/find-service-outlet) and present the following documents:

- your driver's licence or another official photo ID document
- the vehicle registration certificate

### If you cannot come to the service outlet in person

- If you are an individual, the person who goes to the service outlet to request a temporary registration certificate for you must bring the original of the [Power of Attorney (PDF, 657.0 KB)⁠](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/blob/saaq/documents/formulaires/power-attorney-form.pdf) form completed by you.
- If your business owns the vehicle and none of its directors can be present, the person responsible for requesting the registration certificate must bring the original of a document authorizing that person to act on its behalf.

## Vehicle registered for operation in a location that is not connected to the Québec road network

We can issue a temporary 1-month registration certificate for a passenger vehicle registered for operation in a location that is not connected to the Québec road network. During that month, the vehicle will be allowed to travel on any public roads.

### To request a 1-month certificate

Go to one of our [service outlets](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/find-service-outlet) and present:

- your driver's licence or another official photo ID document

### If you cannot come to the service outlet in person

- If you are an individual, the person who goes to the service outlet to request a temporary registration certificate for you must bring the original of the [Power of Attorney (PDF, 657.0 KB)⁠](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/blob/saaq/documents/formulaires/power-attorney-form.pdf) form completed by you.
- If your business owns the vehicle and none of its directors can be present, the person responsible for requesting the registration certificate must bring the original of a document authorizing that person to act on its behalf.

## Trip permit for a heavy vehicle

If you own a heavy vehicle registered in another Canadian province or territory, or in the United States, and used for the transportation of goods or passengers in Québec, you must obtain a trip permit.

A trip permit is valid for 10 days and allows the vehicle to be driven through Québec or to go a particular location in Québec and return to the point of origin.

A trip permit is not required if the vehicle is registered under [IRP](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/vehicle-registration/vehicle-international-registration-plan) and fees have been paid for Québec.

### To request a trip permit

Go to one of our [service outlets](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/find-service-outlet) and present the following documents:

- your driver's licence or another official photo ID document
- the vehicle registration certificate or a photocopy of the registration certificate
- the fuel tax registration number provided by [Revenu Québec⁠ ⁠](https://www.revenuquebec.ca/en/) **or** the licence issued in accordance with the [International Fuel Tax Agreement (IFTA)](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/en/transportation-goods/transportation-outside-quebec/fuel-tax)

### If you cannot come to the service outlet in person

- If you are an individual, the person who goes to the service outlet to request a temporary registration certificate for you must bring the original of the [Power of Attorney (PDF, 657.0 KB)⁠](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/blob/saaq/documents/formulaires/power-attorney-form.pdf) form completed by you.
- If your business owns the vehicle and none of its directors can be present, the person responsible for requesting the registration certificate must bring the original of a document authorizing the person to act on its behalf.

## Recalibration of the advanced driver assistance systems after a severely damaged vehicle has been rebuilt

We can issue a temporary 12-hour registration certificate so that you can have a rebuilt vehicle’s advanced driver assistance systems recalibrated

### Important

- The vehicle may only be operated if it is covered by civil liability insurance for at least $50,000.
- The certificate is valid only if all the other repairs have been made, including those to the body, frame, structural components, air bag system and alignment.

### To request a certificate

The vehicle owner or that person’s representative must go to one of our service outlets to request the temporary certificate.

If recalibration of the advanced driver assistance systems cannot be completed within the 12-hour period covered by the first temporary certificate, you can go back to the service outlet and request a second one. Note that a maximum of two certificates can be issued by going to a service outlet. After that, another process applies (see below).

Before going to the service outlet, make sure the vehicle is registered in your name. If it is not, you must bring the required documents to have the vehicle transferred to your name.

### If you cannot come to the service outlet in person

- If you are an individual, the person who goes to the service outlet to request a temporary registration certificate for you must bring the original of the [Power of Attorney (PDF, 657.0 KB)⁠](https://saaq.gouv.qc.ca/blob/saaq/documents/formulaires/power-attorney-form.pdf) form completed by you.
- If your business owns the vehicle and none of its directors can be present, the person responsible for requesting the registration certificate must bring the original of a document authorizing that person to act on its behalf.

If more time is required to successfully complete the recalibration even after you have been issued two temporary registration certificates in a service outlet, you can apply for a third certificate. However, in this case, you must mail your written application to one of the addresses provided below.

If you are an individual:

Société de l’assurance automobile du Québec

Service aux particuliers

Demande de certificat temporaire

333, boulevard Jean-Lesage, N-3-14

Québec (Québec)  G1K 8J6

If you are a business:

Société de l’assurance automobile du Québec

Service aux entreprises

Demande de certificat temporaire

333, boulevard Jean-Lesage C-3-33

Québec (Québec)  G1K 8J6

Your application must contain the following information:

- Your first and last name
- Your driver’s licence number
- The name of the business you represent, if applicable
- Your address
- Your telephone number
- The vehicle identification number
- The reason why you need another temporary registration certificate
- The date for which you would like the certificate to be issued (allow for 14 business days)
- The address the certificate is to be sent to, if different from your address

You must include with your application:

- Copies of both invoices for the recalibration carried out on the two days for which the previous temporary registration certificates were issued
- Copies of both diagnostic reports showing that the recalibration had not been successfully completed

Last update: December 18, 2024
